I’m still trying to decide whether he sits up above Le Carré and PD James. I’m not sure, but he’s certainly in the same league. Havana Bay has him putting his research skills and his imagination on the line again and succeeding brilliantly. Just as he imagined Russia and Russians flawlessly in the previous three books, he does the same in a Cubano-Russian setting this time. I’m again floored. I’ve been to Cuba, more than once, and I couldn’t possibly imagine how he got the kind of detail that he’s showing in the book. And not just physical detail, but details about the inner lives and pressures in a closed society. How does he do it? I was stunned by Gorky Park, his first Arkady Renko novel, and I’m just as amazed by Havana Bay. What a talent. It must be fun to research and imagine endlessly, slowly putting it together. But it’s a grind as well. I’m envious, either way.Anyway, Renko hits rock bottom this time, worse than being on the slime line in Polar Star, but he manages to claw his way back up, only to see it all…. Well, no need to spoil anything. Another great piece of work from the absolute master. I am in awe.

summary: Book 4/8 in the Arkady Renko Series When the corpse of a Russian is hauled from the oily waters of Havana Bay, Arkady Renko comes to Cuba to identify the body. Looking for the killer, he discovers a city of faded loneliness, unexpected danger, and bewildering contradictions. His investigation introduces him to a beautiful Cuban policewoman; to the rituals of Santeria; to an American fugitive and a group of ruthless mercenaries. In this place where all things Russian are despised, where Hemingway fished and the KGB flourished, where the hint of music is always in the air, Arkady finds a trail of deceit that reaches halfway around the world–and a reason to relish his own life again.
